column2: semiaquatic rodents of the Holarctic. There are two extant species
column3: the North American beaver (Castor canadensis) and Eurasian beaver (C. fiber). Beavers are the second largest rodents after the capybaras. They have stout bodies with large heads
column8: scaly tails. The animals can be found in a number of freshwater habitats
column11: lakes and ponds. They are herbivorous and primarily consume the tree bark
column12: but may also eat aquatic plants

column1: Beavers are known for building dams and lodges using tree branches
column2: vegetation
column3: rocks and mud. They use their incisors to chew down trees for their branches. Dams serve to impound water and lodges serve as shelters. Beavers are considered to be keystone species
column4: and their infrastructure creates wetlands that are used by many other species. Adult males and females live in monogamous pairs with their kits and yearlings. Beavers are highly territorial and mark them using scent mounts made of mud
column6: a urine based substance excreted through the beaver's castor sacs.

column1: Beavers have historically been hunted for their fur
column2: meat and castoreum. Castoreum has been used in medicine
column3: perfume and food flavoring. Beaver pelts have been a major driver of the fur trade. Both species have been decimated due to overhunting but protections starting in the 19th and early 20th centuries have allowed their populations to rebound. Both species are listed as least concern by the IUCN Red List of mammals. The beaver is famed for its industriousness and its building skills. It has also been a popular symbol in Canada.

column1: The English word "beaver" comes from the Old English word beofor or befer (recorded earlier as bebr)
column2: which in turn sprang from the Proto-Germanic root *bebruz. Cognates in other Germanic languages include the Old Saxon bibar
column3: the Old Norse bjorr
column4: the Middle Dutch and Dutch bever
column6: the Old High German bibar and the Modern German Biber. The Proto-Germanic word in turn came from the Proto-Indo-European (PIE) word *bhebhrus
column7: a reduplication of the PIE root *bher-
column9: whose own descendants now include the Lithuanian bebras and the Czech bobr
column10: as well as the Germanic forms. The genus name Castor is Latin and derives from the Greek kastor which translates as "beaver" or "he who excels".

column1: There are two extant species of beavers: the North American beaver (Castor canadensis) and the Eurasian beaver (C. fiber). The genus Castor was coined by Carl Linnaeus in 1758 who also classified the species name fiber. C. canadensis was classified in 1820 by German zoologist Heinrich Kuhl. However
column2: the two beavers were not conclusively shown to be separate species until the 1970s with chromosomal evidence. Prior to that
column3: many still considered them the same species. As many as 24 subspecies have been classified for C. canadensis while 9 have been for C. fiber. The North American beaver has 40 chromosomes while the Eurasian beaver has 48. The North American beaver has a larger skull with a broader tail. In addition
column4: the nostrils of the North American beaver are square shaped while those of the Eurasian species are triangular.

column1: Beavers belong to the rodent suborder Castorimorpha along with Heteromyidae (kangaroo rats
column2: kangaroo mice
column3: pocket mice and spiny pocket mice) and the gophers. Modern beavers are the only extant members of the family Castoridae. Castoridae originated in North America in the late Eocene and dispersed into Eurasia via the Bering Land Bridge in the early Oligocene coinciding with the Grande Coupure
column4: a time of great faunal turnover around 33 million years ago (mya).The more basal castorids had features such as more complex occlusion between the cheek teeth
column6: premolars close to the molars in size
column7: the presence of a third set of premolars (P3) and the stapedius muscle
column8: smooth palatine bone with a posteriorly located palatine foramen and an elongated rostrum. More derived castorids have less complex occlusion
column9: upper tooth rows which diverge posteriorly
column10: larger second premolars in comparison to molars
column11: loss of P3 and stapedius and more grooved palatine with a palatine foramen shifted towards the front. Members of the subfamily Palaeocastorinae appeared in late Oligocene North America. This group was small-bodied and adapted to a fossorial or burrowing lifestyle
column14: broad skull and short tail.In the early Miocene (about 24 mya)
column15: castorids evolved a semiaquatic lifestyle and developed the ability to cut down trees and build infrastructure
column16: an ability that allowed them to survive in the harsh winters of Arctic latitudes. It appears that these behaviors started as a side effect to the consumption of wood and bark. Members of the subfamily Castoroidinae appeared around this time and includes giants like Castoroides of North America and  Trogontherium of Eurasia. Members of this group appear to have been less specialized for aquatic life than modern beavers.There is evidence that least one genus in Castoroidinae
column18: ate bark and built dams and lodges. Researchers suggest that eating bark and building are unlikely to have evolved twice
column19: so modern beavers and Castoroidinae shared a wood-eating common ancestor. Dipoides appears to have been a rather poor builder than modern beavers. The genus Castor likely originated in Eurasia and the ancestors of the North American beaver would have entered North America across the Bering Land Bridge in the late Miocene (8–7.6 mya). The lineages of the two beaver species are estimated to have split around 7.5 mya.

column1: Beavers are the second largest rodents after the capybaras. They have a head-body length of 80–120 cm (31–47 in)
column2: with a 25–50 cm (9.8–19.7 in) tail
column3: a shoulder height of 30–60 cm (12–24 in) and a weight of 11–30 kg (24–66 lb). Their bodies are drop-shaped like other aquatic animals. A beaver coat has 12
column5: 000 hairs/cm³ and functions to keep the animal warm
column6: help it float in the water and protect against the teeth and claws of predators. Guard hairs are 5–6 cm (2.0–2.4 in) long and typically reddish brown
column7: but can range from yellowish brown to nearly black; while the underfur are 2–3 cm (0.79–1.18 in) long and dark gray. Beavers molt during the summer.Beavers have massive skulls which are adapted for withstanding the forces generated by their powerful chewing muscles. Their four incisors are chisel-shaped with continuous growth. The outer enamel of the incisors is very thick and colored orange due to the presence of iron. The roots of the lower incisors extend throughout the length of the lower jaw. Beavers have two premolars and six molars for each jaw adding up to 20 teeth in total. The molars have meandering ridges on a flat surface for grinding woody food. The eyes
column8: ears and nostrils are arranged so that they can remain above water when the rest of the body submerges. The nostrils and ears have valves that close underwater while nictitating membranes cover the eyes. Their lips can close behind the incisors
column9: allowing for chewing in water. Beavers typically spend 5–6 minutes underwater per dive but they can hold their breath for as long as 15 minutes.

column1: The front feet of the beaver are dexterous
column2: allowing them to grasp and manipulate objects as well as dig and groom. The hind feet are larger and have webbing in-between the toes which they use for swimming. The second claw of the hindfoot is split and is used for combing the fur to keep it fluffy. Perhaps the most distinctive feature of the beaver is its flat
column3: scaly tail. The tail has multiple functions. It props up the animal when it is cutting down a tree and acts as a rudder when it is swimming and maneuvering underwater. It also stores fat and has a countercurrent blood vessel system which allows the animal to reduce heat loss by 25% during the summer and 2% in the winter. Despite popular depictions
column4: beavers do not use their tails to pack or carry mud.The beaver digestive system is adapted for a high-fiber diet; a cardiac gland secretes into the stomach. Its intestine is six-times longer than its body and the caecum is twice the volume of its stomach. The fecal matter of the beaver takes the form of balls of sawdust which it deposits into the water. The sex organs of a beaver are located within the body. Beavers have one opening
column7: digestive and excretory openings. This may serve to reduce areas for infections when swimming in dirty waters. Beavers have two castor sacs
column8: which are found between the kidneys and urinary bladder and open into the urethra
column9: and anal glands. The castor sacs secrete castoreum
column11: which is mainly used for marking territory. Anal glands produce an oily substance which beavers use to rub on their fur to make it waterproof. It also plays a role in individual and family recognition.Compared to many other rodents
column12: the brain of a beaver has a smaller hypothalamus in relation to the cerebrum with a ratio of hypothalamus to cerebrum length ranging from 0.20–0.24; this indicates a relatively advanced brain with higher intelligence. The cerebellum is well-developed
column13: giving the beaver coordination in three-dimensional space (such as underwater). The neocortex is mainly dedicated to touch and hearing. The former is more advanced in the lips and hands than the whiskers and tail. Vison in the beaver is comparably poor and the beaver eye is not as well adapted to seeing underwater as that of an otter. Beavers have an acute sense of smell which is particularly important for sniffing out scent marks as well as detecting land predators.

column1: Both beaver species are listed as least concern by the IUCN Red List of mammals. The North American beaver is widespread throughout the continent down to northern Mexico; being absent only in the Arctic
column2: the deserts of the southwestern US and in peninsular Florida. The species was also introduced to Finland
column3: where it spread to other parts of Europe (and coexists with the Eurasian species)
column7: the North American beaver was trapped and almost extirpated because its fur and castoreum were highly sought after. With protections in the late 19th and early 20th centuries
column8: the beaver population has rebounded to an estimated 10 to 15 million by the early 21 century; this is a fraction of the originally estimated 100 to 200 million North American beavers before the days of the fur trade.The Eurasian beaver's range is less continuous. It was historically widespread throughout Europe and Asia
column9: but overhunting greatly reduced its range by the early 20th century. In Europe
column10: beavers were reduced to isolated populations in the Rhône of France
column13: the Neman river and Dnieper Basin in Belarus and the Voronezh river in Russia; their combined numbered estimated at 1
column14: 200 individuals. The beaver has since returned to parts of its former range due to management measures and reintroductions. Beaver populations currently range from Spain and France
column15: though central and eastern Europe and into Scandinavia and western Russia and their population totaled at least 639
column17: beavers have also been reintroduced to parts of Great Britain. Small populations are also present in Mongolia and northwestern China
column18: their numbers estimated at 300 and 700 respectively as of 2016.

column1: Beavers live in freshwater ecosystems like rivers
column2: streams
column3: lakes and ponds. Water is the most important part of beaver habitat and they require a yearly supply that is sufficient enough for swimming
column6: protection of entrances to their lodges
column7: and safety from land-dwelling predators such as canids
column8: felids and bears. Beavers tend to be cautious when on land and escape into the water when they sense a threat. With streams
column9: beavers prefer to utilize slow-moving water
column10: typically with a gradient or steepness of 1%
column11: though they have been recorded using streams with gradients as high as 15%. Wider streams around 8 m (26 ft) are used more than narrower ones around 1.4 m (4 ft 7 in). Beavers typically avoid areas with regular flooding
column12: and may abandon a place for years after a significant flood.Beavers prefer areas with flatter terrain but can be found in mountainous areas. Trees and shrubs are needed for building lodges and dams. They can fall trees at an average of 1.24 minutes per plant. This can depend on the circumference of the trunks; those 25 cm (9.8 in) and larger require over four hours. North American beavers prefer aspen trees while Eurasian beavers prefer willow. Both tree species grow quickly and have soft wood for chewing and peeling. North America beavers can colonize an area where aspen is around 60 m (200 ft) from the water
column13: but can harvest trees several hundred meters away. Beavers can harvest other tree species such as maples
column16: beech and hornbeam. In areas with no trees
column17: beavers may use brush.Beavers have an herbivorous and generalist diet. They eat tree bark; while non-woody plants consumed include aquatic plants like water-shields and lilies
column20: grasses and sedges. Beavers also take agricultural crops like maize and sugar beets. Dispersing beavers will use certain habitats temporarily before arriving at their final destinations
column21: particularly in spring. These include small streams
column23: ditches and even backyards. These sites lack important resources and the animals do not stay there long. Beavers have increasingly settled at or near human-made environments
column26: golf courses and even shopping malls.

column1: Beaver dams serve to impound flowing water and submerge the entrance to their homes. The enclosed water also allows the floating of building material
column2: depths to dive for safety and a wider area for feeding. This is not needed for lake-dwelling beavers and thus they do not build dams. Dams consist of logs
column3: rocks
column4: wads of grass and mud. They can be as low as 20 cm (8 in) to as high as 3 m (10 ft) tall and can stretch 0.3 m (1 ft 0 in) to several hundred meters long.How a beaver builds a dam depends on water flow. With shallow stagnant water
column5: the animals slowly build up mud
column6: leaves and small twigs. With large streams
column7: a more solid base is needed. Beaver use log poles
column8: around 2 m (6 ft 7 in) long and 5 cm (2.0 in) around
column9: to brace against the banks and align in the direction of the water flow and at an angle of 30 degrees. These poles are weighed down by heavy rocks with grass stuffed in-between them. Beavers continue to pile on more material
column10: until the dam settles into a compact slope on the enclosed side.Beavers use shelters for protection from the weather and predators
column11: as well as sites for eating
column15: birthing and rearing. They may dig tunnels
column17: into steep-sloped banks with entrances underwater. In some cases
column18: they may pile sticks over and around the entrance
column19: creating bank lodges. The most complex are freestanding open-water lodges that are built over a platform in shallow water and consist of sturdy logs and mud. The entrances to it are submerged under the water and the roof is sealed up with mud aside from an air vent at the top.

column1: All three structures can be present at a beaver site. Beavers tend to use the bank lodges during the summer
column2: which are around 2 °C (36 °F) cooler than the surrounding air. Open-water lodges are used during the winter and their temperature is similar to that of the surrounding water
column3: at around 0.5 °C (32.9 °F). The air vent provides ventilation
column4: and carbon dioxide can clear out in 60 minutes. The amount of oxygen and carbon dioxide in a lodge does not change much with the seasons. During the winter
column5: warm air coming out of the vent helps melt the snow and ice on the lodge.Beaver lodges are typically small and sloppy for first time settlers but more experienced families can build fortresses that are 6 m (20 ft) in diameter and 2 m (6 ft 7 in) high. Lodge building takes place mainly at night and one sturdy enough to withstand the coming winter can be built in just two nights. Dams and lodges built by North American beavers tend to be more advanced. In addition
column6: Eurasian beavers tend to build more bank lodges while North American beavers build more open-water ones. Beavers will also cache their food for the winter
column7: piling up branches and saplings next to their lodge.Beavers create trails as they wander onto land and wear down vegetation
column8: particularly by dragging tree limbs back to the water. If the ground is level
column9: these trails may fill with water
column10: becoming canals. Beavers will make them deeper by digging up mud. These trails can stretch 15–18 m (49–59 ft)
column11: or even longer in tree depleted areas. Canals can make transporting logs to the pond easier. Beaver families may also dig channels at the bottom of their pond
column12: which can retain water during a drought.

column1: The beaver works as a keystone species in an ecosystem by creating wetlands that are used by many other species. Next to humans
column2: no other extant animal appears to do more to shape its landscape. When building their dams and lodges
column3: beavers alter the paths of streams and rivers and allow for the creation of extensive wetland habitats. Beaver ponds
column4: and the wetlands that succeed them
column5: remove sediments and pollutants from waterways
column9: carbon and silicates. One study found that engineering by beavers leads to a 33 percent increase in the number of herbaceous plant species at riversides. Another study found that beavers increase wild salmon populations. The presence of beaver dams has also been shown to have a positive effect on trout by increasing either the number of fish
column11: or both. Contrary to popular myth
column12: most beaver dams do not pose barriers to trout and salmon migration
column13: although they may be restricted seasonally during periods of low stream flows.Beavers help waterfowl by creating increased areas of water
column15: they thaw areas of open water
column16: allowing an earlier nesting season. In a study of Wyoming streams and rivers
column17: watercourses with beavers had 75-fold more ducks than those without. Widening of the riparian terrace alongside streams is associated with beaver dams and has been shown to increase riparian bird abundance and diversity
column18: an impact that may be especially important in semiarid climates. As trees are drowned by rising beaver impoundments
column19: they become ideal nesting sites for woodpeckers
column20: which carve cavities that attract many other bird species. Fish-eating birds use beaver ponds for foraging and in some areas
column21: certain species appeared more frequently where beaver were active than at sites with no beaver activity. Beaver modifications to streams in Poland have been associated with increased bat activity. While overall bat activity was increased
column24: activity may be hampered in locations where beaver ponds allow for increased presence of duckweed.

column1: Beavers and humans can conflict over land use. Individuals that change the environment in ways that are unwelcome by humans are known as "nuisance beavers". The impounded water caused by dams can damage crops
column2: tree plantations
column3: roads and recreational areas. In addition
column4: the water held by dams can be dangerous if the structure breaks too quickly. Beavers may also consume crops and fall economically important trees.Introduced beavers at Tierra del Fuego have destroyed around sixteen million hectares of indigenous forest. Unlike many trees in North America
column5: trees in South America often do not regenerate when cut down. The ponds they have created certain have flooded other trees and vegetation. With no natural predators
column6: the animals have spread beyond Tierra del Fuego itself into the Brunswick Peninsula of Chile
column7: and the government fears further penetration into continental South America. However
column8: areas with introduced beaver were associated with increased populations of native puye fish (Galaxias maculatus)
column9: whereas the exotic species had negative effects on native stream fishes in the Cape Horn Biosphere Reserve
column10: Chile. Beavers are classed as a "prohibited new organism" under New Zealand's Hazardous Substances and New Organisms Act 1996
column11: preventing them from legally being imported into the country.Beavers may also contribute to climate change. The structures they build flood valleys and form lakes which then cause permafrost to thaw and release methane in Arctic areas. As this gas is released to the atmosphere
column12: climate change ensues. The beavers' recent migration and habitation in the Alaskan tundra is escalating this danger.

column2: being active at night. They spend the daytime in their shelters and during the first half of the night they forage and during the second half they do construction. In some areas
column3: beaver activity is decoupled from the 24-hour cycle
column4: particularly during winter when confined to their lodge and may have an activity-cycle of as much as 28 hours.

column1: The basic units of beaver social organization are families consisting of an adult male and adult female in a monogamous pair and their kits and yearlings. Beaver families can have as many as ten members in addition to the monogamous pair. Groups this size or close to this size build more lodges to live in while smaller families usually need only one. However
column2: large families have been recorded living in one lodge. Beaver pairs mate for life; however
column3: if a beaver's mate dies
column4: it will partner with another one. Extra-pair copulations also occur. Females may have their first estrus cycle of the season in late December and peak in mid-January. Females may enter estrus two to four times per season and each cycle lasts 12–24 hours. Mating typically takes place in the water but may also occur in the lodge
column5: and lasts 30 seconds to 3 minutes. Gestation may last 104–111 days
column6: with three or four kits being born.Both the male and female take part in raising offspring. When young are born
column7: they spend their first month in the lodge and their mother is the primary caretaker while their father maintains the territory. In the time after they leave the lodge for the first time
column8: yearlings will help their parents build food caches in the fall and repair dams and lodges. Still
column9: adults do the majority of the work and young beavers help their parents and are dependent on them for food and for learning life skills. Young beavers spend most of their time playing but also copy their parents' behavior. However
column10: while copying behavior helps imprint life skills in young beavers
column11: it is not necessarily immediately beneficial for parents as the young beaver do not perform the tasks as well as the parents. Beaver kits are weaned at ten weeks.

column2: which are around two years old
column3: may also live in families and help their parents. In addition to helping build food caches and repairing the dam
column4: two-year-olds will also help in caring for the younger offsrping. While these helping two-year-olds increase the chance of survival for younger offspring
column5: they are not essential for the family
column6: and two-year-olds stay and help their families only if there is a shortage of resources in times of food shortage
column8: or drought. Beavers typically leave their parental colony at 23 months old
column9: and usually do not settle far. Beavers can recognize their kin by detecting differences in anal gland secretion composition using their keen sense of smell. Related beavers share more features in their anal gland secretion profile than unrelated beavers. Being able to recognize kin is important for beaver social behavior
column10: and it causes more tolerant behavior among neighboring beavers.Within the lodge
column11: beavers communicate with burgs and whines. They produce gargles and bubbles when entering and exiting. When outside
column13: which involve an animal hitting the water surface with its tail
column14: serve as alarm signals for a potential threat. The tail slap of an adult is more successful in alerting the entire family
column15: which escape into the lodge. Adults normally ignore those of juveniles who have not yet learned the proper use of a tail-slap.

column1: Beavers maintain and defend territories which contain the dams
column2: canals
column3: trails and food caches while the outside feeding areas are encompassed within a home range. They invest much energy in their territories
column4: building their dams and becoming familiar with the area. Beavers mark their territories by constructing scent mounts made of mud
column5: debris and castoreum. Most scent mounts are established near the border of the territory.Because they invest so much energy in their territories
column6: beavers are intolerant of intruders and the holder of the territory is more likely to escalate an aggressive encounter. These encounters are often violent. To avoid such situations
column7: a beaver marks its territory with as many scent mounds as possible
column8: signaling to intruders that the territory holder has enough energy to maintain its territory and is thus able to put up a good defense. As such
column9: territories with more scent mounts are avoided more often than ones with fewer mounts. Scent marking increases in spring during the dispersal of yearlings
column10: in an attempt to prevent them from intruding on territories. Beavers also exhibit a behavior known as the "dear enemy effect". A territory-holding beaver will investigate and become familiar with the scents of its neighbors. As such they respond less aggressively to intrusions by their territorial neighbors than those made by non-territorial floaters or "strangers".

column2: trapped and exploited for their fur
column3: meat and castoreum. Castoreum was used for a variety of medical purposes; Pliny the Elder suggested that it could treat vertigo
column7: stomach diseases and epilepsy. He also stated that it could cure hiccups when mixed with vinegar
column8: toothaches if mixed with oil and injected into the ear on the same side and could be used as an antivenom. Castoreum was described in the 1911 British Pharmaceutical Codex for use in dysmenorrhea and hysterical conditions (i.e. pertaining to the womb)
column9: for raising blood pressure and increasing cardiac output. The activity of castoreum has been credited to the accumulation of salicin from willow trees in the Eurasian beaver's diet
column10: which is transformed to salicylic acid and has an action very similar to aspirin.The musky odor of the substance has also lent itself as an ingredient in perfumes
column11: and has also been used for food flavorings. Ancient people appear to have believed
column13: that the castor sacs of the beaver were its testicles.  Aesop's Fables describes beavers chewing off their testicles to preserve themselves from hunters
column14: (which is not possible because the beaver's testicles are inside its body) and this myth has persisted for centuries.Beavers were also hunted for their fur. They were particularly easy to find for trappers as they stayed in one place. Trappers will kill entire families in a lodge. Beaver pelts were mainly used to make hats. A beaver hat was considered a luxury item in 17th century England and were commonly stolen. The fur trade in North America was mainly built on the beaver and pelts were valuable enough to cause or contribute to the Beaver Wars
column15: King William's War and the French and Indian War. Fur traders were the main driver of the westward expansion of Europeans into the continent and fur traders were the first to meet and negotiate with the native peoples
column16: who capitalized on trading with the Europeans. Between 1860 and 1870
column17: the peak of the fur trade
column18: the Hudson's Bay Company as well as the fur companies in the US
column20: 000 beaver pelts per year.The Catholic Church traditionally considered the beaver to be part beast and part fish. The scaly
column21: fish-like tail was allowed to be eaten on meatless Fridays during Lent. Beaver tails were a delicacy in medieval Europe and were described as having the flavor of a nicely dressed eel.

column2: the beaver is famed for its industriousness and its building skills. They have also lent themselves to everyday language. The English verb "to beaver" means to work hard and constantly and a "beaver intellect" refers to a slow but honest mentality. The name "beaver" is also used as a slang term for beards and the female genitalia.In a Haida tale
column3: a raven tried to steal salmon from beavers by rolling up their stream like a carpet but had to keep stopping to rest at treetops. The beaver followed and kept gnawing down the tree
column4: causing the raven to keep losing fish and water. In a Cree story
column5: the trickster Wisakedjak hacked at the lodge and dam of the Great Beaver. However
column6: the beaver used its power to stop the water from rushing though and caused the water to build up and flood the world.Beavers were often depicted fantastically in medieval European art
column8: given dagger-like tusks or even fish-tails. They were identified as beavers by being given visible testicles. Beavers also appear in Dante Alighieri's Divine Comedy and in the writings of Athanasius Kircher
column9: who wrote that when the beavers entered Noah's Ark they were given a stall near to a water-filled tub which they shared with mermaids and otters. The anthropomorphic Mr. and Mrs. Beaver have an important role in the plot of The Lion
column11: first part of C.S.Lewis' The Chronicles of Narnia. Beavers have also been featured in animated series such as the The Angry Beavers and Happy Tree Friends.

column1: The importance of the beaver in the development of Canada through the fur trade led to its official designation as the national animal in 1975. The animal has long been associated with Canada
column2: appearing on the coat of arms of the Hudson's Bay Company in 1678. It is depicted on the Canadian five-cent piece and was on the first pictorial postage stamp issued in the Canadian colonies in 1851 (the so-called "Three-Penny Beaver"). The city of Montreal and the Canadian Pacific Railway bear the beaver on their crest or coat of arms. The beaver has also been used in heraldry in Europe
column3: including the coats of arms of the city of Biberach and the University of Oxford.

column1: Beaver Tracks: How to identify beaver tracks in the wild
